security_audit.summary: Official Anthropic skill for creating algorithmic art with p5.js. No malicious code, proper licensing, educational focus. All code is client-side generative art with no external dependencies beyond p5.js CDN.

content.value_statement: Create interactive generative art using p5.js with seeded randomness and parametric exploration, enabling users to generate unique visual pieces and explore variations through an intuitive interface.
actual_capabilities: Generate algorithmic art using p5.js and Perlin noise
Create seeded random outputs for reproducible results
Provide interactive parameter controls (sliders, color pickers)
Implement particle systems, flow fields, and procedural generation
Create self-contained HTML artifacts with embedded p5.js
Design custom parameter spaces for different algorithmic aesthetics
limitations: Requires browser support for p5.js (modern browsers only)
Canvas size limited by browser rendering capabilities (~1200x1200px optimal)
Animation performance depends on particle count and client hardware
Color controls optional—some artworks may use fixed palettes
Requires user to write custom p5.js algorithm for each artistic vision
No server-side processing; all computation is client-side

prompt_templates.title: Flow Field Art
prompt_templates.prompt: Create an algorithmic art piece inspired by organic flow patterns. Use Perlin noise to generate a vector field that guides particles through the canvas. The particles should leave trails that accumulate into dense patterns over time. Make it feel natural and fluid, like wind patterns or water currents.
prompt_templates.scenario: User wants to generate flowing, organic visual patterns

prompt_templates.title: Recursive Structure
prompt_templates.prompt: Design an algorithmic artwork based on recursive branching structures inspired by trees or lightning. Start with a root point and recursively subdivide with slight randomization. Use golden ratio proportions to maintain visual harmony. Vary the recursion depth and angle spread as parameters.

prompt_templates.title: Particle Interference
prompt_templates.prompt: Create an algorithmic artwork where particles exhibit wave-like interference patterns. Initialize particles on a grid where each carries a phase value that evolves through sine waves. When particles are near, their phases interfere—constructive interference creates bright nodes, destructive creates voids.

prompt_templates.title: Stochastic Crystallization
prompt_templates.prompt: Design an artwork using randomized circle packing or Voronoi tessellation. Start with random points and let them evolve through a relaxation algorithm until they reach equilibrium. Color cells based on size, neighbor count, or distance from center to create organic crystalline patterns.
prompt_templates.scenario: User wants mathematical order emerging from randomness

prompt_templates.title: Custom Generative Vision
prompt_templates.prompt: I want to create algorithmic art that [describe aesthetic: flowing, geometric, organic, chaotic, etc.]. The art should express [describe concept/philosophy]. Make it parameterizable so I can explore variations by adjusting [describe what aspects should be tunable].
prompt_templates.scenario: User has specific artistic vision and wants AI to implement it

best_practices: Start with a clear algorithmic philosophy before implementing—this guides all design decisions
Use seeded randomness (randomSeed/noiseSeed) to ensure reproducible outputs for same seed
Keep parameters tunable for exploration—avoid hard-coded values
Organize parameters in a single params object for easy UI connection and reset functionality
Implement both static and animated generation options depending on artistic vision
Use Anthropic's template as the starting point—maintain consistent UI/branding while customizing algorithm
Focus on computational beauty and emergent behavior rather than static image templates
Keep performance in mind—optimize particle counts and calculations for smooth 60fps
Make the algorithm feel 'meticulously crafted'—tune parameters until output appears intentional
Document parameter ranges thoughtfully—narrow ranges for subtle effects, wider for dramatic changes
Test seed navigation thoroughly—previous/next/random/jump should produce expected variations
anti_patterns: Copying existing artists' work directly—create original algorithmic philosophies instead
Hard-coding values instead of parameterizing them—limits exploration and variations
Ignoring seeded randomness—makes outputs non-reproducible and unreliable
Creating from scratch instead of using the provided template—loses branding consistency
Over-complicating with too many parameters—fewer, meaningful controls are better
Making the algorithm feel random and uncontrolled—should appear thoughtfully designed
Using placeholder names like 'TITLE - EDIT' in final output—customize for each artwork
Creating multiple files instead of single self-contained HTML artifact—harder to share
Ignoring performance—heavy algorithms with 50,000+ particles may stutter
Static parameter handling—parameters should update in real-time when possible

faq.question: Do I need to write the p5.js algorithm myself?
faq.answer: Yes, the skill helps you create original algorithmic art. You design the algorithmic philosophy, and Claude implements it in p5.js code. The template and best practices guide implementation, but the algorithm should be unique to your artistic vision.

faq.question: Can I use this without knowing p5.js?
faq.answer: You don't need to write p5.js yourself, but understanding basic concepts (particles, vectors, noise, randomness) helps you communicate your artistic vision to Claude. The skill handles the implementation.

faq.question: What makes the art 'algorithmic' versus just random?
faq.answer: Algorithmic art uses computational rules and processes to generate beauty. It's not random noise—it's controlled chaos. Parameters like seed values, noise scales, and particle behaviors create intentional patterns that feel meticulously crafted.

faq.question: How do I share the generated art?
faq.answer: The output is a self-contained HTML file. Save it, send it via email, host it on a website, or open it in any browser. No server or dependencies needed—everything is embedded in the file.

faq.question: Can I modify the generated HTML after creation?
faq.answer: Yes. The HTML is fully editable. You can adjust parameters, colors, algorithm logic, or UI controls. Code comments mark what's fixed (template) versus variable (your algorithm).

faq.question: What's the difference between seed navigation buttons?
faq.answer: Previous/Next step through seeds sequentially (e.g., 123 → 122 or 124). Random generates a new random seed. Jump-to-seed goes directly to a specific seed number. All produce deterministic outputs for that seed.

faq.question: Why is seeded randomness important?
faq.answer: Seeded randomness ensures that the same seed always produces identical output, enabling reproducibility and variation exploration. Users can save and revisit favorite variations by noting the seed number.

faq.question: Can I export high-resolution images?
faq.answer: The template includes a download button for PNG export. Resolution depends on the canvas size in your algorithm. You can modify the canvas dimensions in the setup() function for higher resolutions.

faq.question: How many parameters should my art have?
faq.answer: 3-5 meaningful parameters are ideal. Too few limits exploration; too many overwhelm users. Choose parameters that significantly affect the output and align with your algorithmic philosophy.

faq.question: What if my algorithm is too slow?
faq.answer: Optimize by: reducing particle counts, simplifying calculations (avoid expensive sqrt/trig functions), using lookup tables, implementing spatial hashing for collisions, or reducing noise octaves. Test performance across different hardware.
